# Introduction

```{r}
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(dplyr)
#library(flextable)

iris_sum <- iris %>% 
  group_by(Species) %>% 
  summarize(
    Sepal.Length = mean(Sepal.Length, na.rm = TRUE),
    Sepal.Width = mean(Sepal.Width, na.rm = TRUE),
    Petal.Length = mean(Petal.Length, na.rm = TRUE),
    Petal.Width = mean(Petal.Width, na.rm = TRUE)
  )

# set_flextable_defaults(

iris_sum |> kable(booktabs = TRUE,

  kableExtra::kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped", "hold_position"),
                full_width = FALSE,

           ) |>
  add_header_above(c("","Sepals" = 2, "Petals"=2)) |>
  pack_rows("Group 1", 1,1) |>
  pack_rows("Group 2", 2, 3)

## R Markdown

@cookbook because it's a good book [@cookbook]

<a href="url">link text</a>

[a citation](www.google.com)

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars, message=TRUE, warning=TRUE}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, fig.cap="This is a plot of `r params$species`."}
to_plot <- subset(iris, Species == params$species)
plot(to_plot$Sepal.Length, to_plot$Sepal.Width)
```
